block.p: LEAD: International A3-11
LEAD: International A3-11
International A3-11
Japan's stock market is strong and stable, churning out record levels of fresh capital for Japanese corporations, which could give them an advantage over their competitors abroad. Page A1
An East German Politburo member met with leaders of New Forum, a month-old opposition movement that the Government originally branded as hostile to the state. A1
A U.S. speech about the Soviet Union was barred by Secretary Baker, who felt it was excessively pessimistic about President Gorbachev's prospects for success, Administration officials said. A1

Four Soviet nuclear submarines based in the Baltic Sea will be destroyed, President Gorbachev said. The move is aimed at building good will in the area and adding pressure for disarmament in Europe. A10
In U.S., little effect seen from Soviet move A10
Shevardnadze urges dismantling of Warsaw Pact and NATO
Flight from the Ruble A11
Coal miners in the Soviet Arctic resume strikes for a day
Israel has helped South Africa develop a medium-range missile, said American officials, basing their remarks on intelligence reports. A1
Britain is in political turmoil as Prime Minister Thatcher's Finance Minister and the Chancellor of the Exchequer both resigned, leaving the country's monetary and economic policy in confusion. A1
John Major: a meteor in Thatcher's political constellation
A6
Sweden's governing political party, the Social Democrats, who have made the nation a generous welfare state, have reached a crossroads and are taking a distinct turn toward the free market. A3
Corazon Aquino will not run again in 1992, she said, despite intense pressure. She said she had done her duty in helping to restore democracy to the Philippines. A5
Martial law's end is seen in China
A8
Jetliner crashes in Taiwan; 54 feared dead
A3
The U.N. Commissioner for Refugees has resigned in a scandal over charges that he misused agency money to pay for entertainment and air travel for himself and his wife, officials said. A6
National A12-16, B6

The G.N.P. grew at a 2.5 percent rate in the quarter that ended in September as a surge in consumer spending offset weakness in exports and the industrial sector, Commerce Department figures showed. A1

Officials of Lincoln Savings and Loan were accused of resorting to wiretapping, political pressure and inducements to regulators to thwart action against the institution, state and Federal regulators said. A1
Profits for auto sales off sharply for Big Three
D1
Regulatory victory for A.T.&T. D1
Gains fight alters U.S. borrowing D1
The World Series resumes today, with the Bay Area hoping that a baseball game will speed the healing of a region rocked to its foundation just 10 days ago. A1
Some earthquake-damaged homes near Santa Cruz, Calif., may be barred from being rebuilt. Geologists are trying to determine whether deep fissures may make some areas too risky for homes. A16

The 1990 military spending bill for major weapons is near completion in a Congressional conference, staff aides said. The allotment for ''Star Wars'' is much less than the Bush Administration had been seeking. A14
Pierce to cite 5th Amendment again
Sponsor of Medicare-repeal plan hints at compromise
Administration divided over move to halt global warming
Michigan bill on abortion consent gains

State plans for toxic waste disposal, which were mandated by the Federal Government, both reinforced regional cooperation and hardened barriers to it, leaving disarray in the East and much of the South. B6
McDonalds's acts to recycle plastic
D1
Drug agents arrested 119 people and raided stores in 46 states that sell horticultural equipment that investigators say is used for growing marijuana indoors, officials said. A12
Prisoners riot for a second day in Pennsylvania
Wisconsin tribe rejects offer for fishing rights B6
Regional B1-5

David Dinkins and Rudolph Giuliani share similar views on many New York City issues. In recent interviews, they expressed concern about the quality of life in the city and the impact of crime and drugs. B1
Governor joins Dinkins attack against Giuliani
B2
Critic's Notebook: TV political ads accentuate the negative
B2
Rivals in Nassau offer differing visions
B5
New York State's budget shortfall for the next fiscal year, starting in April, could be twice what the Cuomo administration had originally forecast. B3
Exxon will move its headquarters and 300 employees from the Exxon Building in Manhattan to a 132-acre office park near Dallas, its chairman said. B3
A choreographer with AIDS is suing two Broadway producers for discrimination. He was dismissed as the choreographer of the show ''Legs Diamond.'' B1

To rid New York City's streets of illegally placed construction materials and related items, the Transportation Department mounted a large clear-out effort, seizing materials and vehicles and issuing summonses. B1
Daily flights to be offered at Stewart Airport
B3
36 are arrested after squatters battle police B1
Ex-Helmsley employee admits guilt in state tax case
B4
